questions.text: Which of the following fungal cell membrane components are primarily targeted by antifungal drugs, such as azoles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Azoles act by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14α-demethylase responsible for ergosterol synthesis, the main sterol in the fungal cell membrane.

Fungal cell structure:

  • Fungi possess a rigid cell wall composed primarily of chitin, β-glucans, and various other polysaccharides, which provides structural support and protection.
  • Beneath the cell wall lies the fungal cell membrane, which has a distinct composition compared to that of animal cells.
  • A key feature is the presence of ergosterol, a sterol unique to fungi that serves the role of cholesterol in animal cell membranes.
  • Pneumocystis species lack ergosterol.
  • Ergosterolis a sterol, similar to cholesterol in animal cells, and it plays a critical role in maintaining the integrity, fluidity, and function of the fungal cell membrane.

Mechanism of action of Azoles:

  • Azole antifungals(e.g., fluconazole, itraconazole) inhibit the fungal cytochrome P450 3A enzyme, lanosterol 14α-demethylase, which is responsible for converting lanosterol to ergosterol.
  • The resulting depletion of ergosterol alters the fluidity of the membrane, and this interferes with the action of membrane-associated enzymes. The net effect is an inhibition of replication.

Explanation of other options:

Chitin Option (A): Chitin is a major structural component of the fungal cell wall, and not a part of the cell membrane. Chitin provides rigidity and helps protect the fungus.

Glucan and mannan Option (B): These polysaccharides are important components of the fungal cell wall. While they contribute to the structure and immune recognition of the fungus, they do not directly impact the cell membrane's integrity or function in the way ergosterol does.

Cholesterol Option (D): Cholesterol is a key component of animal cell membranes, not fungal membranes. Fungi utilise ergosterol in place of cholesterol to perform similar membrane-stabilising functions.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is commonly used for the detection and identification of fungi in clinical microbiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In clinical microbiology, identifying fungal infections is crucial for patient management, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or those with systemic fungal diseases.
  • Various special stains are used to visualise fungi under the microscope, with each stain offering different advantages for different types of fungal structures.
  • Calcofluor white binds to polysaccharides in cellulose and chitin, which fluoresce under ultraviolet light, enhancing the detection of fungi in fluids or tissue sections.
  • Gomori's methenamine silver enhances fungal visualisation by staining fungal cell walls black.
  • After primary isolation of fungi, stains such as lactophenol cotton blue are used to examine fungal growth and to identify organisms by their morphology.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic female presents with oral thrush. The physician suspects an infection caused by Candida albicans and sends a sample for fungal culture. What is the typical pH of culture medium commonly used for the isolation of Candida species?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most commonly used medium for cultivating fungi is Sabouraud’s dextrose agar, which has a pH of 5.6.

  • Sabouraud's dextrose agar is the most commonly used and optimal medium for many fungi.
  • It contains peptone (1%), dextrose (4%) and has a pH of 5.6.
  • The low pH of 5.6 is optimal for the growth of dermatophytes and satisfactory for the growth of many other fungi. Most bacteria fail to grow, or grow poorly, on Sabouraud's agar.
  • Antibacterial agents - chloramphenicol 40 mg or gentamicin 50 mg per litre of medium can also be added to augment the antibacterial effect.
  • Neutral SDA (Emmons' modification) differs from the original SDA in having neopeptone (1%) and dextrose (2%) and a pH of 7.2.

choices.text: Grows as a filamentous form in tissue
Microscopic examination shows spherules with endospores
Grows as a filamentous form in culture at 22-25°C
Grows as a yeast form in the environment

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with subcutaneous nodules on her hands following thorn pricks while gardening. Which of the following is true about the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of subcutaneous nodules on the hands following a thorn prick suggests sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It grows as filamentous forms in culture at 22-25°C.

Sporothrix schenckii:

  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungi, which exist in two forms depending on the temperature:
    • Grows as filamentous forms in culture at 22-25°C and in the environment. (Option A, D ruled out)
    • Grows as yeast forms in culture at 37°C and in tissues.
  • It causes sporotrichosis, also known as Rose Gardener's disease.
  • Disease is characterised by nodular, ulcerating lesions of the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Fungus gains access through thorn pricks, follows the lymphocutaneous spread pattern.

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Histopathological staining of tissue sections reveals asteroid bodies and shows the Splendore-Hoeppel phenomenon.
  • Asteroid body consists of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic mass, composed of antigen-antibody complexes, which is described as the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.
  • Culture
    • At 25°C, it produces mycelial form, consisting of slender, delicate hyphae with conidia arranged in a flower-like pattern.
    • At 37°C, it produces a narrow-based budding yeast cell or a Cigar-shaped yeast cell.

Treatment: Drug of choice is Itraconazole.

Explanation of other options:

Microscopic examination shows spherules with endospores (Option B): Spherules with endospores are seen in Coccidioidomycosis, also known as desert rheumatism/ valley fever/ California disease.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi is not a dimorphic fungus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspergillus species do not exhibit dimorphism. They are moulds in both the environment and in tissue.

  • Some fungal species can transition between morphological forms depending on environmental conditions. These are known as dimorphic fungi.
  • They grow as yeasts in host tissues and cultures at 37°C.
  • While in environments and cultures at 22-25°C exist as hyphal (mycelial) forms.
  • Examples of dimorphic fungi:
    • Blastomyces dermatitidis
    • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
    • Talaromyces marneffei
    • Coccidioides immitis
    • Histoplasma capsulatum
    • Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal groups is classified as Fungi imperfecti?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fungi imperfecti, also known as Deuteromycetes or imperfect fungi.

  • Fungi imperfecti are a group of fungi characterised by the lack of a sexual reproductive stage in their life cycle, hence called so.
  • These fungi reproduce asexually through spores like conidia or other asexual spores.
  • This group include the majority of the medically important fungi.

Taxonomic Classification of Fungi:

Based on the production of sexual spores, the Kingdom Fungi has been divided into four medically important phyla. They are as follows:

  • Zygomycetes: Also called Mucormycetes & Phycomycetes, the sexual spores are known as zygospores. e.g. Rhizopus and Mucor
  • Ascomycetes: They produce sexual spores known as ascospores. e.g. Aspergillus
  • Basidiomycetes: They produce sexual spores known as basidiospores, e.g. Cryptococcus
  • Deuteromycetes (Fungi imperfecti): The sexual state is either absent or unidentified yet. Hence, they are traditionally grouped as fungi imperfecti.

Fungal asexual spores are:

  • Arthrospore
  • Blastospore
  • Chlamydospore

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with fever, cough, and body pain. The findings of microscopic examination of the sputum specimen are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of influenza-like fever with microscopy showing spherules with endospores and barrel-shaped conidia arrangement suggests California valley fever caused by Coccidioides immitis.

Coccidioidomycosis:

  • Also called desert rheumatism, California Valley fever, and San Joaquin Valley fever.
  • The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Coccidioides immitis.
  • It is characterised by mild influenza-like fever to severe pneumonia and shows joint involvement, hence rheumatism.
  • Coccidioidomycosis can cause a chronic and fatal meningitis
  • Being a dimorphic fungus, on culture:
    • Yeast forms shows spherule with endospores.
    • Mould form shows a barrel-shaped arrangement of arthrospores
  • Treatment:
    • Mild disease: fluconazole/itraconazole
    • Disseminated: Amphotericin B followed by itraconazole.

Explanation of other options:

Chicago disease (Option A): Gilchrist disease, North American Blastomycosis and Chicago disease are other names for blastomycosis, caused by the dimorphic fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis. It commonly presents with pulmonary and cutaneous lesions. The yeast form shows broad-based budding with a figure-of-eight appearance, while the mould form has branched hyphae with terminal conidia.

Ohio Valley disease (Option C), Darling's disease (Option D): Both refer to histoplasmosis, caused by the dimorphic fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. The acute form presents with flu-like symptoms, while the chronic form mimics tuberculosis. On biopsy, Giemsa stain reveals intracellular oval budding yeast cells with a narrow base, and the mould form shows tuberculate macroconidia with a characteristic sunflower-like appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a highly infectious agent requiring bio-safety level 3?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cultures of Coccidiodes immitis are highly infectious; may lead to accidental inhalation of spores in laboratories and hence require biosafety level-3 precautions.

Biosafety levels (BSLs) are a set of precautions that isolate dangerous biological agents in a laboratory.

Explanation of other options:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (Option B): This fungus causes paracoccidioidomycosis, which is primarily endemic to parts of Latin America. It is not typically classified as BSL-3.

Blastomyces dermatitidis (Option C): Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis; while it is a significant pathogen, it does not require BSL-3 containment. It is often handled under BSL-2 conditions.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option D): This is the causative agent of histoplasmosis, a systemic granulomatous infection. It generally requires BSL-2 containment in the laboratory, not BSL-3.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with ulcerative cutaneous lesions. Microscopic examination of the specimen revealed findings shown in the image below. Based on the characteristic appearance, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The microscopy image above shows the characteristic Mickey Mouse or mariner's wheel appearance, typical of Paracoccidioides species, the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, also known as Lutz mycosis.

Paracoccidioidomycosis:

  • Also known as South American disease or Lutz mycosis.
  • It's a systemic fungal infection caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.
  • Primarily affects the lungs and can spread to other organs such as the skin, mucous membranes, and lymph nodes.
  • Paracoccidioidomycosis causes disfiguring skin and mucosal lesions,
  • especially in men.
  • Mostly endemic to parts of Latin America, especially in rural areas of Brazil, Argentina, and other countries in the region.
  • Yeast form shows:
    • Pilot wheel appearance
    • Mariner wheel appearance
    • Mickey Mouse appearance.

Explanation of other options:

San Joaquin Valley fever (Option A): San Joaquin Valley Fever, also known as California Valley Fever or Desert Rheumatism, refers to coccidioidomycosis caused by the dimorphic fungus Coccidioides immitis. In culture, the mould form displays barrel-shaped arthroconidia, while the tissue (yeast) form appears as spherules filled with endospores.

Gilchrist disease (Option B), North American Blastomycosis (Option D): Gilchrist disease, North American Blastomycosis and Chicago disease are other names for blastomycosis. It is caused by the dimorphic fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis, which commonly presents with cutaneous and pulmonary symptoms; the yeast form shows broad-based budding with a figure-of-eight appearance, while the mould form has branched hyphae with terminal conidia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with ulcerated, raised, verrucous skin lesions. A skin biopsy was taken, and microscopic examination showed fungal elements with characteristic features as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The microscopy image shows a figure-of-eight appearance, a hallmark feature of Blastomyces dermatitidis, the causative agent of blastomycosis, which is characterised by pulmonary and cutaneous lesions.

Blastomycosis:

  • Also known as North American blastomycosis or Gilchrist's disease, or Chicago disease.
  • The cutaneous form of the disease is most common and presents with nodular, ulcerative lesions, while the pulmonary form resembles TB.
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus, which in:
    • The yeast form shows a figure of 8 appearance or a broad-based budding yeast cell
    • Mould form shows branched terminals with conidia.
  • Treatment:
    • Mild cases: fluconazole or itraconazole
    • Disseminated: amphotericin B followed by itraconazole.

Explanation of other options:

Coccidiodes Immitis (Option A): Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, which presents with joint involvement and influenza-like fever. The mould form of fungi displays barrel-shaped arthroconidia, while the tissue (yeast) form appears as spherules filled with endospores.

Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis (Option B): Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, which primarily affects the lungs. The yeast form of fungus has a Mickey Mouse or mariner's wheel appearance.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option D): This dimorphic fungus causes histoplasmosis, a systemic granulomatous disease. The acute form presents with flu-like symptoms, while the chronic form mimics tuberculosis. Giemsa staining of the biopsy specimen reveals intracellular oval budding yeast cells with a narrow base, and the mould form shows tuberculate macroconidia with a characteristic sunflower-like appearance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent cough for 3 weeks, associated with fever, night sweats, and fatigue. He reports having a dry cough initially, which gradually became productive with occasional blood-tinged sputum. Microscopic examination of the sputum sample is shown below. Based on these findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a persistent cough, fever, night sweats and microscopy showing a sunflower-like appearance is characteristic of histoplasmosis, caused by Histoplasma capsulatum.

Histoplasmosis:

  • Histoplasmosis is a systemic granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • Also known as Darling's disease/Ohio disease/Cave's disease/endemic mycosis.
  • Histoplasma is an intracellular parasite which survives within the phagolysosome of the macrophage by producing alkaline substances, such as bicarbonate and ammonia.
  • Reservoirs are bat/bird droppings, which contaminate the soil and spores are inhaled by humans.

Clinical features

  • Minimally symptomatic, often causing mild fever and cough for a few days or weeks.
  • More severe cases are most often characterised by chills, malaise, chest pain, and more extensive lung infiltrates.
  • Progressive pulmonary disease can mimic pulmonary TB, with sputum production, night sweats, weight loss, and even the development of lung cavities.
  • Disseminated histoplasmosis generally appears as a nonspecific febrile illness in an immunocompromised patient, with enlargement of reticuloendothelial organs, resulting in lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and anaemia.

Lab diagnosis: BM biopsy on Giemsa Gram stain shows:

  • Yeast: Intracellular oval budding yeast cell with a narrow base.
  • Mould: Tuberculate macroconidia (sunflower-like appearance).

Treatment: Amphotericin B, Ketoconazole

Explanation of other options:

Coccidiodes Immitis (Option A): Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, which presents with joint involvement and influenza-like fever. The mould form of fungi displays barrel-shaped arthroconidia, while the tissue (yeast) form appears as spherules filled with endospores.

Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis (Option B): Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, which primarily affects the lungs. The yeast form of fungus has a Mickey Mouse or mariner's wheel appearance.

Blastomyces dermatitidis (Option C): This dimorphic fungus causes blastomycosis, which commonly presents with cutaneous and pulmonary symptoms; the yeast form shows broad-based budding with a figure-of-eight appearance, while the mould form has branched hyphae with terminal conidia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old with systemic mycosis was initiated on treatment with an antifungal agent that targets ergosterol synthesis to disrupt fungal cell membrane integrity. Which of the following drugs is most likely being used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Itraconazole is an azole antifungal drug that inhibits the synthesis of ergosterol.

  • Azole antifungals(e.g., fluconazole, itraconazole) inhibit the fungal cytochrome P450 3A enzyme, lanosterol 14α-demethylase, which is responsible for converting lanosterol to ergosterol.
  • The resulting depletion of ergosterol alters the fluidity of the membrane, and this interferes with the action of membrane-associated enzymes. The net effect is an inhibition of replication.

Explanation of other options:

Flucytosine (Option A): This antifungal drug acts by inhibiting DNA and RNA synthesis, not ergosterol synthesis.

Nystatin (Option B): Nystatin is a polyene antifungal that binds directly to ergosterol, disrupting the fungal cell membrane, but it doesn't inhibit its synthesis.

Griseofulvin (Option D): Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent that acts by disrupting fungal cell division by inhibiting microtubule function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sexual spore in fungal reproduction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Arthrospores are asexual spores, whereas the others are sexual spores.

  • Arthrospores are asexual spores produced by fragmentation of the fungal hyphae (the filamentous structures).
  • The hyphal segments break into individual cells, which can then germinate to form new fungal colonies.

Explanation of other options:

Zygospores (Option A): Zygospores are sexual spores produced by zygomycetes like Rhizopus. They are formed when two compatible haploid gametangia (specialised sexual structures) fuse, resulting in a diploid zygospore. After maturation, the zygospore undergoes meiosis to produce haploid spores.

Ascospores (Option B): Ascospores are produced by Ascomycetes like Aspergillus, Penicillium during sexual reproduction. They are formed within a specialised sac-like structure called an ascus. Typically, eight ascospores are produced per ascus following meiosis.

Basidiospores (Option D): Basidiospores are sexual spores produced by Basidiomycetes (e.g., mushrooms, Cryptococcus). They are formed on a specialised structure called a basidium, where typically four basidiospores are produced after meiosis. Basidiospores are released and can germinate into new mycelia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with patchy hair loss on the scalp. On examination, there are broken hair shafts with greyish-white scaling. Wood's lamp examination reveals fluorescent fungal growth around the hair shaft. Which of the following fungi is most likely the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and examination findings are suggestive of the ectothrix type of tinea capitis, most commonly caused by Microsporum audouinii.

Tinea capitis:

  • Refers to fungal infection of the hair and the scalp, which begins with an erythematous papule around the hair shaft and progresses to scaling of the scalp, discolouration/fracture of the shaft.

Two types of hair infection may be distinguished in wet mounts:

  • Ectothrix
  • Endothrix

Ectothrix:

  • This form of tinea capitis presents in acute and inflammatory forms.
  • Patches are small and slightly erythematous, polycyclic forms, and scales are branny or furfuraceous.
  • Infected hairs have lost natural shine (due to the spores on the surface of the hairs) so covered with a white sheet.
  • Arthrospores are seen as a sheath surrounding the hair shaft.
  • Causative agents:
    • M.gypseum.
    • M.audounii.
    • M.canis.
    • T.rubrum.
    • T.mentagrophytes.

Endothrix:

  • Characteristic signs are Black dots -the hairs are broken off at the scalp surface.
  • Breakage of hair at the follicular orifice creates patches of alopecia with black dots of broken hair.
  • Arthrospore formation occurs within the hair, filling the entire hair shaft.
  • Causative agents: (Option A, C, D ruled out)
    • T.tonsurans.
    • T.violaceum.
    • T.schoenleinii

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presents with a warty lesion on the lower limb following a thorn prick injury. A biopsy is performed, and the microscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation of a warty lesion following a thorn prick injury, along with microscopy revealing copper penny bodies, is characteristic of chromoblastomycosis, which can be caused by Cladosporium species.

Chromoblastomycosis:

  • Chromoblastomycosis, also known as verrucous dermatitis, refers to slow-growing chronic subcutaneous lesions caused by a group of dematiaceous or phaeoid fungi (i.e. darkly pigmented fungi).
  • The disease is mainly tropical and is more common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.
  • The characteristic lesion is a warty, cutaneous nodules which resemble the florets of a cauliflower.
  • Prior history of a thorn prick or wood prick is usually present.

Diagnosis:

  • Biopsy of the warty lesion (H&E or Giemsa stain) shows sclerotic bodies.
  • The sclerotic bodies, also known as brown globose bodies or medlar bodies, give a copper penny appearance.
  • Causative agents:
    • Fonsecaea pedrosi
    • Fonsecaea compacta
    • Phialophora verrucosa and
    • Cladosporium carrionii

Treatment: Amphotericin B and 5-fluorocytosine have been found useful.

Explanation of other options:

Sporothrix (Option A): Sporothrix causes sporotrichosis, a nodular ulcerative skin infection typically following a thorn prick. At 25°C, it produces mycelial form, consisting of slender, delicate hyphae with conidia arranged in a flower-like pattern, while at 37°C, it produces a narrow-based budding yeast cell or a Cigar-shaped yeast cell, and microscopy shows asteroid bodies.

Malassezia furfur (Option C): Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor, a superficial fungal infection of the skin characterised by discrete patches of either hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation, especially on the skin of the torso and upper arms.

Rhinosporidium (Option D): Rhinosporidium seeberi is the causative agent of rhinosporidosis. Bathing in stagnant water and holy dips a risk factors for the condition. It is a chronic granulomatous disease presenting as unilateral or bilateral nasal polyps. Biopsy of the polyp shows spherules with endospores.

questions.text: A premature infant delivered via emergency C-section at 34 weeks is admitted to the NICU due to hypoxia and intrauterine growth restriction. The baby received total parenteral nutrition, following which signs of fungemia developed. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fungemia in a neonate receiving TPN is most commonly caused by Malassezia furfur, a lipid-dependent yeast.

Malassezia furfur:

  • Commonly associated with TPN use, especially in premature infants, due to the high lipid content of TPN solutions that supports the growth of Malassezia.
  • It can lead to systemic infections like fungemia in neonates, particularly those with compromised immunity or in intensive care settings.
  • It causes Tinea versicolor, in which the patient presents with discrete patches of either hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation, especially on the skin of the torso and upper arms.

Diagnosis:

  • 10% KOH mount of skin scrapings digests keratin, revealing the characteristic spaghetti and meatballs or banana and grapes appearance, due to the presence of both hyphae and yeast cells.
  • Malassezia furfur is lipophilic; SDA with olive oil overlay is the ideal medium for culture. Typical fried egg colonies appear after incubating for 5-7 days at 32-35° C.

Fig: Malassezia furfur showing A) Spaghetti and meatballs appearance in 10% KOH; B) Fried egg colonies in SDA with olive oil

Explanation of other options:

T. mentagrophytes (Option A): Trichophyton mentagrophytes is a dermatophyte that causes superficial fungal infections like tinea. It does not cause systemic fungemia.

Madurella griesus (Option B): Madurella grisea is a causative agent of mycetoma, a chronic granulomatous fungal infection of subcutaneous tissue. It typically follows traumatic implantation and presents with subcutaneous swellings and discharging sinuses containing black granules.

Aspergillus (Option D): Aspergillus species are opportunistic fungi that cause aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised hosts. However, it is not lipophilic and is not typically associated with fungemia related to lipid-based TPN.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the dermatologist with complaints of scaly hypopigmented patches on her upper back and chest. Microscopy of skin scrapings on 10% KOH is shown below. Based on the microscopy findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microscopy shows yeast cells and hyphae with spaghetti and meatball appearance, seen in Pityriasis versicolor.

  • Tinea versicolor (or pityriasis versicolor) is a chronic recurrent condition involving the superficial layer (stratum corneum) of skin.
  • Causative agent: Malasezzia furfur < Malasezzia globosa
  • It is characterised by flat, round, scaly patches of hypo- to hyperpigmentation of skin.
  • Lesions are non-inflammatory and non-pruritic (or rarely pruritic)
  • Lesions can be mistaken for vitiligo, but the latter is not scaly.
  • Areas rich in sebaceous glands are commonly involved, such as the neck, chest, or upper arms.
  • Disease is more common in moist, humid areas.

Microscopy:

  • Skin scraping examined with 10% KOH reveals the characteristic spaghetti and meatballs appearance, showing short hyphae along with yeast-like cells.
  • When cultured on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar SDA supplemented with olive oil, Malassezia species form distinctive fried egg colonies.
  • Examination under a Wood's lamp reveals yellow fluorescence of the affected skin.

Treatment:

  • Topical agents such as 10% sulfur ointment or 1-2% imidazole creams
  • In extensive cases, systemic antifungals like itraconazole or fluconazole may be used.

Explanation of other options:

Pityriasis alba (Option A): Pityriasis alba is a common skin condition first characterised by red, scaly patches commonly on the face. These patches resolve, leaving areas of scaling with hypo-pigmentation or lighter colouration. These are often seen in children.

Vitiligo (Option B): An autoimmune disorder characterised by the destruction of melanocytes, resulting in well-demarcated depigmented lesions. The lesions often exhibit an acral distribution and show striking depigmentation. Unlike pityriasis versicolor, the lesions are non-scaly.

Favus (Option D): Favus is a chronic ringworm infection involving hair follicles that leads to alopecia and scarring. Patients will have dense crusting on the scalp. Microscopy of hair shafts will show sparse fungal hyphal growth and the formation of airspaces within the hair shaft.

questions.text: Jock itch is the common name for which of the following cutaneous infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tinea cruris, commonly known as jock itch, is a fungal infection that affects the groin area, inner thighs, and buttocks, caused by dermatophyte fungi.

  • Dermatophytes are a group of fungi that infect only superficial keratinised tissue - skin, hair, and nails.
  • They break down and utilise keratin and are incapable of penetrating subcutaneous tissues.
  • Infections caused are collectively called dermatophytoses, also known as Tinea or ringworm.
  • Dermatophytes are classified into three genera:
    • Trichophyton - Affects hair, skin, and nails
    • Microsporum - Affects hair, skin
    • Epidermophyton - Affects skin, nails

Explanation of other options:

T capitis (Option A): Tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), caused by fungi infecting the scalp.

T barbae (Option B): Tinea barbae is a ringworm infection of the beard or moustache area of the face.

T pedis (Option D): Tinea pedis (athlete's foot), caused by fungi infecting the feet. T. cruris and T. pedis are caused by Epidermophyton flocossum & Tricophyton rubrum (red pigment)

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with fever, chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats for the past month. He works as an archaeologist and recently spent time in caves in the Midwest USA. Examination revealed mild hepatosplenomegaly and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with fine basal rales on chest auscultation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of fever, chronic cough, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis, along with cave exposure in the Midwest, is strongly suggestive of Histoplasmosis, a fungal infection associated with bat and bird droppings.

  • Histoplasmosis is a systemic granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • The yeasts survive within the phagolysosome of the macrophage by producing alkaline substances, such as bicarbonate and ammonia.
  • Also known as Ohio disease/Darling disease/Cave's disease.
  • Reservoirs are bat/bird droppings, which contaminate the soil and spores are inhaled by humans.

Clinical features:

  • Hematogenous spread can cause visceral involvement as deep mycosis or systemic mycosis.
  • Progressive pulmonary disease can mimic pulmonary TB, with sputum production, night sweats, weight loss, and even the development of lung cavities.
  • Cutaneous disease begins as an umbilicated nodule over the skin and can result in granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and anaemia suggest disseminated histoplasmosis, a form of the disease where the infection spreads beyond the lungs to other organs.

Lab diagnosis: BM biopsy on Giemsa Gram stain shows:

  • Yeast: Intracellular oval budding yeast cell with a narrow base.
  • Mould: Tuberculate macroconidia (sunflower-like appearance)

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): Histoplasmosis mimics TB clinically, but has specific environmental exposure.

Coccidioidomycosis (Option C): Coccidioides species are thermally dimorphic fungi endemic in parts of the American West. Acute primary infection with C immitis is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with fever, malaise, dry cough, joint pains, and sometimes a rash. Disseminated forms of the disease can involve the bones, joints, skin, and a progressive chronic meningitis.

Paracoccidioidomycosis (Option B): Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is the cause of paracoccidioidomycosis, a disease limited to tropical and subtropical areas of Central and South America. The disease manifests primarily as chronic mucocutaneous or cutaneous ulcers. The disfiguring ulcers spread slowly and develop a granulomatous mulberry-like base.
